description.narrative: För att förbättra och förlänga livskvalitén för män, kvinnor, flickor och pojkar som lever med och är drabbade av HIV/Aids.
To improve and prolong the quality of life of men, women, boys and girls living with and those affected by HIV and AIDS.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Mashambanzou Medical Care Centre Care, treatment and support were provided and the goal was achieved by having 89.66% of admissions being achieved. 51.66% of the admissions were discharged in good health from the care unit considering the conditions they came. This was an achievement even though the number of deaths remained high. There are clients who took long to respond to treatment, especially those who had genital sores and those who had other social problems which needed to be solved like rejection, loosing accommodation and neglect. Quality care and support was given. There was an improvement in health status and psychosocial well being for clients and their caregivers. Hope was restored and encouragement was given for families to support and care for their relatives. Stigma and discrimination is an evil in the community which still needs to be fought to increase disclosure of HIV status and reduce on defaulting. There is need to continue educating the patients to seek early treatment in order to save life. The triple 90% targets can be achieved only with collaborative efforts from the staff, clients and their support systems especially the family. The “tap of new HIV infections” has to be closed and treatment has to be sort earlieR
Nenyere Day Care Centre At the end of the 3-year project, the children who were enrolled at NDCC were equipped to fit in the formal education setting and the society as a whole. They developed all the 4 main developmental basics of ECD children; that is, physically (motor skills development), intellectually (problem solving and cognitive skills), emotionally (positive coping mechanisms) and socially (moral development). They developed into confident and intelligent boys and girls through the various activities, which were carried out at the centre. Regardless of backgrounds and environments that these children came from, the day care centre managed to improve and correct unfavourable behaviour and personalities adopted from the communities that they came from. The children who required other basic services such as health care services and legal documents were assisted as part of the holistic approach to service provision at the centre.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
